title: Two-Coloring of Complete Graph
content: A two-coloring assigns a Boolean value (red/blue) to each edge of Kₙ. We represent this as a function from pairs of vertices to Bool. The complete graph has edges between all pairs, so the coloring domain is Fin n × Fin n.

title: Symmetric Coloring
content: Since edges are undirected, we require c(i,j) = c(j,i). This symmetry constraint ensures the coloring represents an actual edge coloring of the undirected complete graph.

title: Monochromatic Clique
content: A set S of vertices forms a monochromatic clique of color b if every edge between distinct vertices in S has color b. This is a Kₜ where all edges are the same color.

title: Vertex-Disjoint Sets
content: A collection of vertex sets is disjoint if no two sets share a vertex. This is essential for partitioning: each vertex can belong to at most one clique in the partition.

title: CliquePartition Structure
content: A clique partition consists of: (1) a list of cliques, each of size t, (2) a color for each clique, (3) each clique is monochromatic in its assigned color, and (4) all cliques are vertex-disjoint. The 'leftover' is the count of vertices not covered by any clique.

title: Minimum Leftover for a Coloring
content: For a specific 2-coloring c, minLeftover(c,t) is the minimum number of leftover vertices achievable by any valid partition into monochromatic Kₜ's. This measures how well we can cover this particular coloring.

title: Function f_n(t)
content: f_n(t) is the supremum of minLeftover over all 2-colorings of Kₙ. This is the worst-case leftover for a graph of size n: the adversarial coloring that maximizes the minimum leftover.

title: Function f(t)
content: f(t) is the supremum of f_n(t) over all n. For large enough n, this stabilizes to the value given by the Burr-Erdős-Spencer formula. This is the fundamental quantity Erdős asked about.

title: Moon's Theorem (1966)
content: Moon proved f(3) = 4: when partitioning any 2-colored Kₙ (n ≥ 8) into monochromatic triangles, at most 4 vertices remain uncovered. This is the base case that motivated the general question.

title: Ramsey Numbers
content: R(s,t) is the minimum n such that any 2-coloring of Kₙ contains either a red Kₛ or a blue Kₜ. The connection to f(t) comes from the fact that leftover vertices must avoid large monochromatic cliques.

title: Erdős's Ramsey Bound
content: Erdős observed f(t) < R(t,t) ≤ 4^t. The crude upper bound 4^t comes from the standard Ramsey bound. This shows f(t) grows at most exponentially, but doesn't give the precise rate.

title: Burr-Erdős-Spencer Exact Formula
content: For t ≥ 3 and large n: f(t) = R(t, t-1) + x where 0 ≤ x < t. The correction term x depends on n mod t. This exact characterization is the main result resolving Erdős's problem.

title: Bounds on f(t)
content: The exact formula gives R(t, t-1) ≤ f(t) < R(t, t-1) + t. Since R(t, t-1) ≈ 4^t/√t, this pins down f(t) to within an additive O(t) of the Ramsey number.

title: Root Limit
content: f(t)^{1/t} → 4 as t → ∞. This answers Erdős's first question negatively: the t-th root does NOT tend to 1. The exponential growth rate is 4, matching the Ramsey number growth.

title: Not Linear Growth
content: f(t) is NOT O(t), answering Erdős's second question negatively. The function grows exponentially like 4^t/√t, not linearly. No constant C satisfies f(t) ≤ Ct for all t.
